data.title: An early look at who's running for Regina's city council this fall
data.text:
Article content

With Regina’s 2024 municipal election on the horizon, the Leader-Post is keeping track of who’s running for election — or re-election — this fall.

Voters head to the polls on Nov. 13 to determine who will succeed in winning one of the 11 seats around the horseshoe in Henry Baker Hall for the next four years.

As of Thursday, 14 candidates have emerged with hopes of becoming, or remaining, elected representatives.

Article content

Here’s an early look at what we know so far.

Mayor of Regina

First-term Mayor Sandra Masters declared her intentions to run again for the city’s top spot back in March, citing a desire to continue work started in her first four years.

Her first challenger is 27-year-old Brandon Abtosway, a field tech contractor with SaskTel, who announced his candidacy at the end of July.

His campaign website says his approach is to “get back to the basics” with city spending, capping debt and ending “vanity projects” that keep pushing taxes up.

“I think it’s time we put our priorities in check and focus on key elements that the city relies on every single day,” he said in an announcement video posted to social media.

Ward 1

New to the race as of July is former provincial NDP cabinet minister Joanne Crofford, who is restarting her political career in Regina with a swing at Ward 1.

Crofford was an MLA from 1991 to 2006. She served in a multitude of ministerial positions and vied once for party leadership.

“My long involvement in the Saskatchewan community has led to a firm commitment to close working relationships between government and all sectors of our society,” read her announcement.

Article content

Advertisement 3

Story continues below

This advertisement has not loaded yet, but your article continues below.

Article content

Crofford will battle it out with fellow candidate Jessie Morris, a teacher and librarian. Incumbent Cheryl Stadnichuk announced she will not seek re-election.

Morris’ campaign website lists fiscal responsibility, housing access and environmental sustainability as policy priorities.

Ward 2

Bob Hawkins, first elected in 2012, is running again for another four years against university marketing manager Chidi Igwe and local business owner George Tsiklis. All three declared in June.

Ward 3

This spring, Coun. Andrew Stevens announced he does not intend to run for a third term in Ward 3.

The only alternative currently vying for the vacancy is David Froh, vice-president of the Regina Food Bank who was previously with Economic Development Regina.

Ward 4

Charles Umeh, a local film producer and adviser at Creative Saskatchewan, intends to challenge incumbent Lori Bresciani for Ward 4. Bresciani ran unopposed in 2020, and has yet to state her plans for this fall.

Ward 5

Current councillor John Findura also hasn’t publicly declared whether he will seek a sixth term to represent Ward 5 and no other hopefuls have put their names forward for Ward 5 as of Tuesday.

Advertisement 4

Story continues below

This advertisement has not loaded yet, but your article continues below.

Article content

Ward 6

First elected in 2020, lawyer Dan LeBlanc will run for a third time in Ward 6. Currently, he stands alone on the ballot.

Ward 7

First-time councillor Terina Nelson is looking for a second term as the representative of Ward 7. Nelson’s priorities include seeing “taxpayer dollars used wisely” and “championing initiatives to improve parks, infrastructure and public services,” according to her election announcement.

So far, Nelson will face off once again with Shobna Radons, president of the Regina and District Labour Council, for a second election cycle in a row.

Ward 8

Shanon Zachidniak announced in mid-July that she will be seek re-election in Ward 8.

“I plan to continue championing transparency, accountability, responsible spending, environmental sustainability, and building an inclusive and vibrant community,” she said.

No other candidates have yet announced plans to challenge her.

Ward 9

Incumbent Jason Mancinelli told the Leader-Post in June he has not yet made a decision on whether to run for a third term in Ward 9, but other hopefuls have emerged.

Advertisement 5

Story continues below

This advertisement has not loaded yet, but your article continues below.

Article content

Jeff Soroka, a former RCMP constable and civil engineer, will take another swing at it, having run previously in 2020.

In an email to the Leader-Post, Soroka cited turnover in top city administration and financial transparency for taxpayer dollars as top concerns that led to his decision.

Tanis Wilder will also be on the ballot, claiming the ward “needs an advocate for the northwest on city council.”

Wilder, currently the acting associate dean for the faculty of digital innovation at Saskatchewan Polytechnic, said her focus will be on improving core services and addressing rising property taxes.

Ward 10

Candidate hopeful Tara Jijian announced her intention to run for Ward 10 in a short message posted on social media.

“I am looking forward to working with various committees and representing the residents,” stated the post.

Jijian ran as a Saskatchewan Liberal party candidate in 2016, later serving as the provincial party’s interim leader from 2017 to 2018. She also made an unsuccessful bid for school board trustee with the Regina Catholic School Division in 2016.

First-term councillor Landon Mohl has not publicly stated his plans for the fall.

lkurz@postmedia.com
